unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Describing the Law of Large Numbers
question_text: Which of the following best describes the Law of Large Numbers?

choices.text: The larger the sample size, the larger the margin of error will be when constructing a confidence interval.
When the sample size is sufficiently large, a $t$-test for a population mean can be conducted even if the parent population has a skewed distribution.
As the number of trials grows very large, the relative frequency of an event will approach the theoretical probability of the event.
We can construct a confidence interval for a population proportion when the sample size is sufficiently large.
The larger the number is, the more it will adhere to the law.

solution:
It accurately describes the law of large numbers as it relates to probability.

Choice 'A' is a false statement. As the sample size grows larger, the standard deviation of the sampling distribution will grow smaller. This will create a smaller margin of error in a confidence interval.

Choice 'B' is a true statement. However, it does not describe the Law of Large Numbers. Rather, it relates to a condition that is necessary in order to perform a t-test for a population mean.

Choice 'D' is also a true statement. However, it does not describe the Law of Large Numbers. Rather, it is one of the conditions necessary for the construction of a confidence interval for a population proportion. In general, a sample is considered sufficiently large if:
